Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and the French lost most of the territories that they had conquered since the Revolution. However, Napoleon escaped from Elba in February 1815 and took control of the government once again. The Allies responded by forming

In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch of Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion who ruled around Phthia in central Greece. The Parian Chronicle mentions that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the previously called Graikoi were named Hellenes. Aristotle notes that the Hellenes were related with Grai/Greeks (Meteorologica I.xiv) a native name of a Dorian tribe in Epirus which was used by the Illyrians. He also claims that the great deluge must have occurred in the region around Dodona, where the Selloi dwelt. However, according to the Greek tradition it is more possible that the homeland of the Greeks was originally in central Greece. A modern theory derives the name Greek (Latin Graeci) from Graikos, "inhabitant of Graia/Graea," a town on the coast of Boeotia. Greek colonists from Graia helped to found Cumae (900 BC) in Italy,

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. Brazelton's crimes prompted John J. Valentine, Sr. of Wells, Fargo & Co. to send special agent and future Pima County sheriff Bob Paul to investigate. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. Gordon explained how the Maratha systematically took control over new regions. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch records. Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room for development." The first two 12-inch recordings did not take advantage of the extra length: "Carnegie Drag" was 3:15; "Carnegie Jump", 2:41. But at the second session, on April 30, the two 12-inch recordings were longer: "Embraceable You" was 4:05; "Serenade to a Shylock", 4:32. Another way around the time limitation was to issue a selection on both sides of a single record. Vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean recorded "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean", written by Irving and Jack Kaufman, as two sides of a 10-inch 78 in 1922 for Cameo. An obvious workaround for longer recordings was to release a set of records. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes into fragments on a hard floor, spilling the liquid. In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. The causes of the resultant structure and shape of the cup and the encapsulation of the water by the hand within the cup are not easily attributable, as neither hand nor floor can achieve such formations of the cup or water. The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the possibility of war was anticipated by the state government and it began to reinforce the defense lines along the political boundary with Texas. Supplies of weapons were sent to fully equip the military and took steps to improve efficiency at the presidios. Later, the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border were organized by the state which were made up of: light cavalry, four squads of two brigades, and a small force of 14 men and 42 officials at the price of 160,603 pesos per year. During the beginning of the 1840s, private citizens took it upon themselves to stop the commercial caravans of supplies from the United States, but being so far away from the large suppliers in central Mexico the caravan was allowed to continue in March 1844.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to guard the 24-kilometre route, which began at Olympic Park, which was built when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. An adolescent 's environment plays a huge role in their identity development . While most adolescent studies are conducted on white , middle class children , studies show that the racial disparities in adolescents can lead to more adverse behavior in life from early youth to adulthood . In addition to the racial disparities in adolescence that exist , a new study suggests that economic disparities may be contributing much of the racial differences that exists in adolescent identity . A recent study on a subset of high school students in Washington D . C has discovered that among the high school students from all racial groups , the black students were significantly more likely to identify with low status groups , such as African Americans , Hispanics , gang members , the poor , and disabled . This group of black high school students were also more likely to feel that they are victims of injustice and have a higher expectation for negative consequences from their circumstances . Compared to other team sports , the National Football League preseason is very structured . Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year , two at home and two on the road . While the NFL season does not get around to determining rankings until Week 1 of the regular season , NFL pre- season games are determined mostly with a simple formula . This formula consists of a player� s performance during the pre- season and his team � s performance during the season . In a vacuum the NFL could start using the pre- season standings to rank teams and determine its own weekly rankings , but the NFL does not do that . Instead the NFL has the teams share their rankings with the media. The team with the highest ranking after four weeks of regular season play wins the title , a procedure known as . In practice , not all rule violations will result in a disqualification as the referee may use their own judgement and is not obligated to stop the match . Usually , if a referee stops the match if they deem the actions of one fighter are detrimental to the health of their own fighter , it could be considered as a fair decision , as in the case where one fighter was in a vulnerable position. In fact , the majority of rule violations have nothing to do with the safety of the fighter which is what referees are there to decide . The majority of fighters are judged more on their ability to perform rather than their ability to take punishment and it is only in rare instances where a fighter , who is not healthy or who poses a risk to safety , is disqualified due to injury that we know of. There are various reasons for the stopp age which can range from minor to serious injuries .

Mammalian hair , also known as pelage , can vary in color between populations , organisms within a population , and even on the individual organism . Light-dark color variation in hair is an important trait among mammals , and it has traditionally been associated with sex and age . With this in mind , in the 1960 s researchers were interested in the role of age in pelage coloration , which then was called `` pig mented aging , '' and a single color gene , melanoc ortin , was identified as responsible for this phenomenon . Because melanoc ortin affects color ation , and because males and females of a species carry the same allele , it is unlikely that melan oc or tin determines hair color ation in a species , and it might be that , in addition to an age effect , we do not know every factor which affects hair color . I am interested in investigating the role of age and sex in influencing hair color

Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles give a long critique of the application of FST to human populations in their 2003 paper `` Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races , and show that F ST values between 0 .01 and 0 .02 tend to be more biologically significant than those from 0 .05 and above . They say that , even in the relatively hom ogeneous world of East Asia , the F ST ranges from 0 .00 75 to 0 . 005 . They suggest that the observed variation is probably a consequence of the population bottleneck at the end of the last glacial maximum about 21 000 years ago . As population growth proceeds , the F ST should rise at a faster pace than this . Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom , the political structure of which served in most instances [ citation needed ] as a model for the creation of national par liaments in other regions . Under the Westminster system of parliamentary representation , the United Kingdom had two chambers ( one House of Peers and the other House of Commons ) with an absolute majority of members who can make constitutional and legislation [ citation needed ] changes . In the absence of such major reforms , the British system of parliament was often compared with other national parliam ents such as Canada , Brazil , India , New Zealand , United States , etc , and used as a model [ citation needed ] for the creation of more stable and more responsive governments . Such a system allowed the United Kingdom to remain politically divided in times of crisis , whereas other European nations were united immediately when the crisis hit. In the past century

The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma . During the early Jurassic , the supercontinent Pangaea broke up into the northern supercontinent Laurasia and the southern super continent Gond wana , that persisted for approximately 50 million years . Over this time , as G ondwana and Laur asia broke apart , massive volcan ism occurred on their margins . In the north , two distinct eruptions gave rise to the Crato Formation , at about 210 . A single episode of massive volcanic and seismic activity about 170 Ma led to the collapse of some of the large volcanic provinces of the Laurent ides mountain range . Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood ; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals . As a result , oxygen carries better to the cells . Birds are much more adapt able than mammals to maintain a high concentration of blood Oxygen even when exposed to low concentration of oxygen. This ability is because mammals have a complex set of oxygen carrying molecules called hemodynamic regulators . They control the concentration of gas exchange volume and the blood pressure . These regulators are activated by the concentration of oxygen . When the blood pressure drops , these hemodynamic regulators lower the concentration of oxygen in the blood . However many times when mammals are in hyp oxia , they lose their ability to control the activity of these hem odynamic regulators . This causes the concentration of oxygen in blood to rise . When Nintendo released the NES in the US , the design styling was deliberately different from that of other game consoles . Nintendo wanted to distinguish its product from those created by competitor companies at the time , who were often cheap and low quality alternatives sold in supermarkets as well as department stores , or in stores targeted at children .  Nintendo also wanted to develop its games as an adult- oriented entertainment product , which was unusual in the early 1980s. Nintendo opted out of the strategy employed by many of its competitors at the time ; Nintendo also opted to develop its own game production system to make its games easier to produce . In retrospect , it would seem obvious that Nintendo was a step ahead of its competitors , however in the early 1980s , it was an uncommon idea to develop a product from the ground up as an adult game oriented entertainment product , especially one with the gameplay of many different game genres

A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing . Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way , the true predator simply kills the prey , whether it be out of a fear of being eaten themselves or even just out of a desire to eat their prey.  A true predator can be quite different to one that normally attacks things but can do so more successfully through fear , surprise , instinct or hunger.  The difference between the real monster and the fictional creature is often only skin deep . An animal that normally eats animals will also frequently kill and eat humans . Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War , the effects of the conflict were profound , both at home and abroad . Much of Europe ’ s population was traumat ised and destroyed , and it was many years before the UK achieved a full recovery . Since 1945 , there has been an ongoing struggle about the meaning , purpose and purpose of Western involvement in world affairs . In the UK , one of the main political and cultural questions arising from the war has been the British government� s policy on Northern Ireland . Many think that Britain should have tried to reach a political settlement long before the end of the war , but was forced to join in the invasion of six counties in Ulster . Many believe that those who argue for an end to the conflict are del uded . Others , like Paul Corcor an , believe that the war demonstrated that peace is not possible in the Middle East

On 13 March , the upper Clyde port of Clydebank near Glasgow was bombed . All but seven of its 12,000 houses were damaged . Many more ports were attacked in the following 11 months – a total of some 25 attacks – and , as we have seen , were carried out either by German aircraft or British warships patrolling them . German submarines were also responsible for bombing port facilities but on very few occasions were these carried out with success . Only the port of Liverpool was a victim on a regular basis after the war – though it had suffered heavily in the First World War . The port became a target only a few days after the German raid on Liverpool on 30 November and the following day it was hit by a pair of torpedoes , each of which was sunk by the British submarine , the only submarine lost during the whole war . Both hits occurred on the night and no damage was caused .

The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only . A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws . A board -only organization is simply governed by a board and has no membership or other voting rights . The former is considered a `` nonprofit corporation , `` ' and the latter as a social service or cooperative corporation. The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire . Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as `` invasions `` or `` migr ations `` ( 1 , 2 ) , the major political trends were relatively constant . The decline of the Roman Empire was accompanied by a marked change in the nature of the political system . As a consequence of this change , there was a loss of political authority for major cities , but an increasing authority for local groups with strong political claims and an expanded role for urban governments . This phenomenon , termed political `` fusion , `` is described in this paper by looking in more detail at several central European examples . The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south , although the northern ( primarily Germany , France and Great Britain ) and southern universities ( primarily England , and Scotland and Ireland ) shared much culture , especially the language , literature and history.  The culture of the south has become strongly English , as part of which language differences are accepted . The Anglo /German culture in northern Europe developed in opposition to the cultural influence of the Arabic -speaking culture in countries of the Middle East and North Africa , while the northern European culture developed as the result of a counterrevolution against the cultural influence of the French and the German. The academic culture of the northern countries became increasingly English , while the southern countries remained strongly Franc ophone .  The university culture of England has become less English than the academic culture in North America and the southern countries are more English than their northern counterpart.

The Yale Report of 1828 was a dogmatic defense of the Latin and Greek curriculum against critics who wanted more courses in modern languages , mathematics , and science . It argued that if young men were trained well in Greek and Latin , then those languages would not only become indispensable in the curriculum but also lead to a better- informed , well rounded , more enlightened public. Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease . In a microbial culture , a growth medium is provided for a specific agent . A sample taken from an infected individual is treated with a bacterium or other microbe to bring about growth of the microbe . After incubation , the growth of the micro be indicates a presence of the microbe in the sample , the micro be that is inoc ulated is referred to as the 'culture ' , and finally the sample is analyzed for the presence of the microbe 's toxin 's , ant igens and other metabolites .  The method is used clinically to determine the presence of disease -ca using micro be . Microbe culture may be rapid and inexpensive , yet the culture methods , especially those involving cell culture and molecular methods , are complex and require a highly professional , well trained staff , who carry out the procedure carefully and correctly . A negative culture should not be equalled

While the Space Race has been portrayed by animated movies , an entire universe of Space Race games have been developed , including Sput nik by Bats ume , Gosh Jog oro by Nih on Fal com , Starflight by G ekka com & T r amod com , Asteroids by M . U .. , and many others . The Space Race and modern day space flight are related through the use of computers and computer networking , and it is also the subject of ongoing academic work and a popular hobby. To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing , sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated . This is achieved by Neutral Sections ( NS ) . The NS is defined as the portion of the line feeder station fed out- of- phase from the main feeder of which there are two or more stations connected by common feed er lines . Note that all NS 's are grounded.  Note that neutral sections are distinct from unground ed circuits defined by the line feeder ( and possibly other ) neutral lines .  This distinction is important even though many of the feed er stations which supply neutral sections in this example .  However , there can only be one neutral section per line feed er . Similarly for a load fed circuit , there are only a limited number of neutral sections per load feeder station .   Note that these types of neutral sections are often confused under the assumption that they can be combined

Most fatty acids are non-essential , meaning the body can produce them as needed , generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so . However , if a fatty acid is essential , that is , if the fatty acid is indispensable to life , then it must be synthes ized on demand . So while some fat- soluble vitamins and mineral can be manufactured by the body , this is relatively rare. But , even when they are essential , fat- soluble vitamins are not synthes ized by ordinary metabolism . In the case of vitamin D , which also comes in four different forms , the liver synthesizes it , which makes Vitamin D bioavailable . But the vitamin is fat - soluble , so its body supply is relatively limited. As we learn from studies of the vitamin D – deficiency , the body can not synthesize the various forms of the vitamin . Truman , himself a combat veteran of World War I , issued Executive Order 9808 establishing the President 's Committee for War Damage Control . It was used to describe a molecule or combination of molecules that was found to have antimicrobial properties . A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each , known as halves . Each half runs continuously , meaning that the clock is not stopped for time -outs . The game ends when one side wins two goals . The teams and officials who oversee the game are known as officials .  Soccer games between teams from the same country are not governed by the Laws of the Game but by rules . The International Football Association Board , which is a semi- governmental organisation , sets these .  Rules , which are set down in the FIFA Laws of the Game are also enforced . These laws govern the players , referees , goals and field . Rules and the official match clock ensure games run smoothly . If a referee , one of the officials , makes a mistake by incorrectly awarding a goal , or if a game ends by a mistake , the game remains as it stands.  Soccer is a game

Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills . Peer groups offer members the opportunity to develop friendships and to share their thoughts with others . Through group interaction , adolescents are able to discuss how and why they think these beliefs and attitudes are formed . These group activities are often referred to as `` active learning '' activities and have been widely investigated by researchers for their impact on social development . Unfortunately , there is a lack of research that focuses on the impact peer groups have on adolescent development . This is especially worrisome because adolescents have little peer support in the form of group activities and are more likely to turn to one another to form support networks . In 1681 , in partial repayment of a debt , Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony . Despite the royal charter , the colonists refused to recognize his authority and declared that Penn and his heirs did not hold any formal government office . Three years into the American Revolution , the charter was declared void and Britain took full control over the colony . After the Revolution the new US government passed additional legislation granting the rights of private landowners . Penn continued to work for the crown , lobbying Congress for the new rights . He died in 1699 and left his colony to the church ( the Pennsylvania Society for the Prop agation of the Christian Religion ) in 1699 . In 1717 a new charter was signed granting the colonies additional privileges . A central teaching of Jehovah 's Witnesses is that the current world era , or `` system of things '' , entered the `` last days '' in 1914 and , so they say , will eventually come to an end . However , because it has taken a mere 150 years or so to manifest , these predictions are subject to wide variance and some would question their reliability . This presentation will look at the first 150 years since 1914 , and will discuss the current world system , what the Witnesses have observed with regard to its development and the various signs ( or events ) which the Witnesses see as giving rise to it. We will discuss evidence and predictions concerning , for example , the coming of the `` end times `` , the re -em ergence of Jesus in 1948 , and the recent predictions made by the Witnesses with respect to the Great New World Order . The Empire was established in 1336 by Harihara I and his brother Bukka Raya I of Sangama Dynasty . The empire rose to prominence as a culmination of attempts by various ruling clans to establish themselves over their rival factions . Initially it was a kingdom with no capital city and no unified governmental structure other than that of the family members . Later the capital was located at Ch ittag uchi in present day West Bengal. The em perors were initially from the Ray ya ( Raya ) clan ( the great Hindu dynasty ) led by Harihara who was also the first Emperor . Buk ka Ray a and Hars ha were the successors of Har ihara . The vast Seleucid Empire was , like Egypt , mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite . The Greek population of the cities who formed the dominant elite were reinforced by other Greek speaking migrants from Macedonia and mainland Greece . The Sele ucid Empire was a military oligarchy . The ruling family ( the Olyn thiai ) lived in a palace at the top of the city of Sele ucia , the capital of the empire . By the middle part of the 2 nd cent ure B C Rome had replaced the Sele ucid Empire as the dominant superpower in the Mediterranean , with the power to raise an army that in turn could field a navy to conquer the eastern continents . The Sele ucid Empire had become a great trading nation with a very highly developed economic system  using the raw materials of Egypt . Van Praag states that the Ming court established diplomatic delegations with Tibet merely to secure urgently needed horses . Wang and Nyima argue that these were not diplomatic delegations at all . The reason for the Ming court 's failure is not the inadequ acy of Tibetan military equipment , or the lack of communication between Ming soldiers and Tibetan troops . Chinese military failures are largely a result of Chinese leaders and politicians 's lack of self intro re c tive character . This paper provides a critical examination of Chinese military doctrine and an account of how Chinese leaders in the late Ming dynasty conceived of the ' war against Tibet ' ( Wang and Ny ima 2013 ) . Ideas for affirmative action came as early as the Reconstruction Era ( 1865-1877 ) in which a former slave population lacked the skills and resources for sustainable living . In an attempt to compensate , white lawmakers passed laws that would allow blacks to compete in public works and public schools . However , the system never worked.  The same people who are accused of making up affirmative action in an effort to give minorities an unfair advantage are the same people who have benefited from that system . Plumage is regularly moulted ; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the `` non-breeding '' plumage , or—in the Humphrey-Parkes terminology— '' nonbreeding plumage `` or `` `` in bud `` plum age .   Generally , birds that m oult outside the breeding season are called `` non- breed ers . `` They may be males , females , or immature . Most birds that do not breed can be identified by the amount of black pigment on the wings .  When a bird is m oulting , the black pigment is darkened , to the degree that the wings bear a black patch , known as a plum age bar . A red patch is not unusual . For birds , the `` non- breeding plum age `` is the `` non -breeding » plum age . The plum age is the age at which the bird is most likely to survive , so the most effective and most humane way to kill it

Predators are often another organism 's prey , and likewise prey are often predators . Though blue jays prey on insects , they may in turn be prey for cats and domestic dogs . In the wild , predation is typically a mutual ( i .e . non -pred atory ) relationship . Predator animals will prey upon their potential prey while predators may be prey for another predator animals . It is only in captivity is it acceptable to ' own ' a single predator animal . Most animals in captivity have a ' human ' predator , and a 'human ' prey . Though predators are often kept in a small enclosure , some have a large enclosure , though many have no other than the smallest space possible . This is not uncommon for animals in captivity that live in cold climates , such as arctic foxes( as do many carniv ores in polar areas ) . Animals kept in captivity may develop respiratory issues due to the confinement

United States of America : The torch relay 's North American leg occurred in San Francisco , California on April 9 . On the day of the relay officials diverted the torch from passing through the Pacific coast states to a course through the southern states. All participants , however , departed California at 1 A .M and were supposed to converge at the starting point in New York City within 24 hours of the official departure . The relay began with hundreds of runners at the Union Square station , with the torch . The torch was then passed from runner to runner with music being played . A runner dressed in the robes of a Native American ran with the torch and after all the runners passed and the music stopped , the relay was officially finished. It was the 1 ,300 mile long relay that culminated at the foot of the Statue of Liberty in Manhattan . The torch relay was a fundraiser for cancer research .

As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms , the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century . There are a wealth of material records that exist for the era , from historical texts to coins and papy ri . One of the more important is a recently discovered law code known as the Codex The odos of the Oth ones , first published in 1910 . This text offers a rare glimpse into how Roman law was applied by local ch ieftains in the Empire in the mid 5th century , as it deals with a variety of topics from the legal system to personal matters . A second codex from Northern France that is similar in its format and content was written in a region in Roman Britain that did not form a part of the Empire . Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials . They were closely modeled after the mosaics of the Roman baths .  In some instances , U mayy ad mosaic has been identified with other Islamic works . According to the classical archae ologist Ibn -Sa if , they were often decorated with motif s and paintings .  The mosaics also featured animals , and , as did many of the larger Roman mosa ics , they were adorned with human or animal figures , usually allegorical figures or portraits . The panels were constructed from sandstone cut from the slopes of Mt. Harad , the highest point in Ar ad and the most arid area of the desert. Their size varied considerably . Some street trams ( streetcars ) used conduit third-rail current collection . The third rail was below street level . The tram picked up the current through a plough ( sawto oth pickup - no spanners ) .  The third- rail current would not have crossed the street . The tram could not have passed underneath any overhead current , as the current would have short ed through the street . If the tram did reach the overhead third rail , it would have been at a ground level with the third rail below.  But with high current and so much resistance , one tram could easily be driven over the third rail , where it could cause a fire.  So the conductor and conductors would have been killed , and the third rail was installed for good security from the passengers . The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 ( 47 sq mi ) , and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin ( the highest volcan oes , the M vumi u , reach over 300 m ) . The island is covered with salt plains , salt lakes , rocky shores , and beaches , while there are a number of ancient settlements , ruins , and natural monuments . The total population in 1993 was approximately 2 ,000 inhabitants and 50 , 000 people during the British colonial period ( 1817 –18 52 ) . There were 8 78 living on the island in 1950 , and 7 ,000 in 1990.  The island is located in the region of the tropical western Atlantic Ocean , and the prevailing wind is from the northeast .   It has a large and dense population density which limits the impact of fires . The island has an annual precipitation of 100 mm ( 4 .8 in ) .

Innocent , he thought , might be influenced to join this course of action by a pap al injunction enjoining the Catholic bishops to take all possible steps to compel the emperor to surrender his right to rule . Innocent was more worried about the threat to his own power posed by the alliance of John and Louis of Br abant , and the Pope tried again to take John to Rome . The Canadian football field is 150 yards ( 137 m ) long and 65 yards ( 59 m ) wide with end zones 20 yards ( 18 m ) deep . With the addition of video refereeing in the early 1990 s , all Canadian Football League games have been decided in the last seconds of the 4th quarter or overtime .  In addition to the regular- season games , Canadian Football League teams compete in one or more Playoffs ( now playoffs ) in December and January . Teams can field four Canadian and up to six U . S . players on any single regular- season game . The CFL is a college based , American Football style football league where players are paid on a team `` based on a salary cap `` . In 1939 , the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations . Among those on the list were many leading scientists , intellectuals , artists , politicians , and clergy , as well as several hundred civilians from cities throughout the United States.  ( See also , Civil ian Detention . )  In 1940 , a court in New York granted the government authority to detain non combatants and held them in military stock ades until their trials . The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has had a significant impact on biodiversity.  Hybridisation is recognised by the International Union for Conservation of Nature ( I UCN ) as an established and naturally occurring process in the animal kingdom. Where conservation is necessary by the I UCN for the preservation of a species or of a sub species the deliberate intervention must never cause more harm than good . Despite this the deliberate interbreeding of animals for conservation purposes is becoming a significant problem within zoo collections worldwide. In the case of elephants , the consequences have been profound . There is a huge difference between the captive breeding of wild elephants for their exhibit , but in captive zoos for the conservation of native populations there is potential to significantly reduce the populations as a result of hybridisation , breeding programmes and captive in breeding .

The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name . The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s .  The university , while often referred to as `` Irish `` , was not considered an `` Irish University `` . In the 1920s , it drew students from Ireland as well as other countries . Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N , and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas : the Swiss Alps to the south , the Alpine Switzerland to the north , and the rest of Switzerland to the north and northeast . The cantons around Luc erne , A argau , Bern , and Aig ertal also comprise various other regions of the country , of which Zurich and St Gallen are the largest . Switzerland was in the past an administrative part of Germany ; today it has no diplomatic relations with it , but it is in its `` family `` with five other European nations , the German states of Austria , of Lie chten , of Dan ding , and of Lie ge . As a result of an amendment to the German constitution , Switzerland is a part of Germany , and in German the language is commonly spoken in the country . In December , Beyoncé along with a variety of other celebrities teamed up and produced a video campaign for `` Demand A Plan '' , a bipartisan effort by a number of public health groups . The video aimed to help people understand the various facets of a plan to prevent gun violence . The video was created especially to educate people of color who are not likely to be influenced by mainstream media . And it seems the video did n't have the intended effect. In a press release about the video 's release , Clinton 's campaign noted that it had been viewed by an estimated 1 . 7 million people -- and that was before it aired on MSNBC 's 'The Rachel Madd ow Show . By the following day , however , the number of views for the video had grown to an estimated 8 million . It appears that the video was intended for minority groups that could have a strong personal connection to the issue .

As Muslim institutions of higher learning , the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf . In central and eastern Islamic lands , the view that the madrasa , as a whole , is a wa qf had a long history from which Islam emerged as a distinct faith . In its present form , it exists in areas of central Asia , Central Asia , South Asia , and the Indian sub continent . And is viewed as having the same status as a mosque. The word madras a that denotes mad rasa , means a place for education and , is derived from two Arabic words and the root meaning of a place , and r asa , meaning to make it . A school is therefore an open place in which people from various parts of the society can come and study .  Â Many of these institutions are Islamic in nature and are open to all .
